answers.answer: You don't need to be fasting for Thyroid bloodwork.I asked my GP about the best time to have blood taken. He said it didn't really matter, although first thing in the morning may show levels a little lower.Two years ago your TSH was .9, which is supposed to be perfect. It may have changed since then.Ask for a test of TSH, free T3, free T4, and antibodies. With those numbers to look at a good GP can tell you if you have a thyroid problem or not.If your neck glands are swolen, maybe an ultrasound of your glands would be helpful.

Would also have a cortisol test.  The darkening of the skin and the rashes is symptomatic of adrenal problems, also.  This is also not a fasting test, either.  Just like AR, I don't know why they would want you fasting.  But then again I think I read where Graves Lady mentioned that she does fasting ones.  Don't know.  Guess whatever makes you and the dr happy.Let us know what you find out.  Hope they figure out something soon for you.Dac

Has anyone ever worked you up for polycystic ovarian syndrome?  (pcos).  It can often be hard to diagnose but it could be the cause for the fertility problems.  To me it sounds like many of your issues could be autoimmune related - hashi or grave's (thyroid), pcos (reproductive), Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (tiredness), fibromyalgia (cramping assuming you mean muscles & joints), Irritable Bowel Disorders (digestive) and a multitude of skin-related ones.  If you have 1 autoimmune disorder you're at higher risk of getting more.  If you aren't already seening an endocrinologist I would suggest you see one and especially one that specialized in thyroid care and not diabetes care.  They would also be able to check you for any adrenal problems, too.  The other potential issues could be looked at by a rheumatologist and a GI for the GI symptoms.Like Dac said, please let us know what happens and feel free to ask any questions you have.  Welcome to the board.Rayne
